intro: Rubus koehleri var. casparyi, commonly known as the Caspary’s blackberry, is a variant of the blackberry plant native to the mountainous regions of Central America. It is characterized by its dense, thorny shrubs and dark purple to black berries that ripen in late summer. The leaves are typically trifoliate, with serrated edges and a slightly hairy texture. This plant thrives in well-drained soils and partial shade, often found in humid, forested environments. Its berries are valued for their flavor and are sometimes used in local cuisines and traditional medicine.
